author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefano Montali
title: But How Does the Book Sound?
description: In August, The Times began publishing regular reviews of audiobooks, a booming segment of the publishing industry.
content: For about a decade, Elena Sheppard has reviewed books, mostly fiction, including several novels for The New York Times. It’s safe to say she knows the art well. But in June, an unexpected request landed in her email inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: What happened during SpaceX’s Starship test flight.
description: Elon Musk’s SpaceX launched its Starship rocket from the coast of South Texas just after 7 a.m. Central time on Saturday, a mammoth vehicle that could alter the future of space transportation and help NASA return astronauts to the moon.
content: Elon Musk’s SpaceX launched its Starship rocket from the coast of South Texas just after 7 a.m. Central time on Saturday, a mammoth vehicle that could alter the future of space transportation and help NASA return astronauts to the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gal Koplewitz
title: They survived Hamas’s attack on a trance party. An ad hoc center with art and music is helping them heal.
description: For some who had taken psychedelics at the event, the traumatic effects may have been compounded. A group of caregivers joined together to help.
content: The gunning down of hundreds of partygoers at Tribe of Nova, a trance party in Re’im, Israel, in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 terrorist attacks has wrought an outpouring of grief for those killed or taken hostage. Yet while the more than 1,000 attendees who survived may feel lucky to be alive, many are still grappling with the aftermath of the horrifying experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Sex Workers Have Been Shunned by Banks, Even When Their Work Is Legal
description: Financial service companies often avoid what they deem high-risk industries like adult entertainment. When workers lose their accounts, they are left with few options.
content: Bella Cummins has run Bella’s Hacienda Ranch, her Nevada brothel, for nearly four decades — and for four decades, she’s been shunned by much of the banking industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Janfaza
title: In a Six-Point Star, a Multitude of Meanings
description: Wearing Star of David necklaces and other Judaica has become a way for some Jewish people to declare their heritage amid a rise in antisemitism.
content: About four years ago, after the deadly shooting at a synagogue in Poway, Calif., in April 2019, Abby Adams and Sammy Gabbai started an Instagram account to share stories of Jewish solidarity. The account, Why I Wear My Star, featured posts containing people’s reasons for wearing Star of David jewelry and other Judaica.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can Nikki Haley Beat Trump?
description: Imagining the unlikely scenario where she actually wins the nomination.
content: It’s time to admit that I underestimated Nikki Haley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Many Details of Sam Altman’s Ouster Are Murky. But Some Things Are Clear.
description: Everything seemed to be going his way. Then his time at OpenAI was over.
content: All over Silicon Valley, phones lit up on Friday with the same question: What the heck happened to Sam Altman?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Excuse Me While I Do My Holiday Preset
description: Some people are pulling back — in socializing, spending, eating — not to avoid Covid, but to bolster their mental health.
content: Right after Halloween, Ashley Guerra started being inundated with invitations — for Friendsgiving, for holiday parties and for New Year’s Eve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Tiffany Hsu
title: More Advertisers Halt Spending on X in Growing Backlash Against Musk
description: Warner Bros. and Sony have joined other companies in pausing spending on X, formerly Twitter, over Elon Musk’s endorsement of an antisemitic post.
content: More major advertisers have paused their spending on X, the social media service formerly known as Twitter, as the backlash continued over Elon Musk’s endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory on X.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Cade Metz, Erin Griffith and Tripp Mickle
title: Ousted OpenAI C.E.O. Makes Plans for New Artificial Intelligence Company
description: Sam Altman, who was forced out of his company on Friday afternoon, was quickly moving to create another company with another OpenAI executive who quit on Friday.
content: Sam Altman, the tech entrepreneur who was removed as chief executive of OpenAI on Friday by its board of directors, is in the process of pitching a new artificial intelligence start-up to investors, according to three people familiar with his plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Writer With Good Taste?
description: Hoang-Kim Vu serves up a themeless for puzzle gourmets.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — ’Tis the season for holiday puzzle entries, and this grid by Hoang-Kim Vu debuts a great one. There are also a lot of references to festivities and foods, some of them subtle — give your finished solve a once-over and you’ll see what I mean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Nikki Haley Says She Would Have Signed Six-Week Abortion Ban as Governor
description: The former governor of South Carolina, who has tried to thread the needle on abortion in the G.O.P. race, made a gesture of support for stricter limits on the procedure.
content: Former Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina has tried to carve a more moderate path on the contentious issue of abortion than many of her rivals for the Republican nomination for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Robert Moses Put Monkeys in a Park in Harlem. They’re Finally Gone.
description: The iron monkeys with shackled wrists were mentioned in “The Power Broker,” which was published nearly 50 years ago, but had remained mounted in a Riverside Park playground until recently.
content: At first glance, the metal trellis adorning a public bathroom in a playground in Riverside Park may have appeared innocuous. It was made up of four posts, each decorated with a long-tailed iron monkey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: A Thanksgiving Road Map
description: We have a plan to help you prepare for the holiday — and stay sane.
content: Last Thanksgiving, just as a jubilant Santa Claus was making his way across 34th Street on TV, I noticed something alarming in the kitchen of my childhood home. The oven I had preheated for my stuffing had not, in fact, heated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Bluestone
title: The Bergdorf Blonde Moves to Park Avenue
description: The location has changed, but clients such as Hillary Clinton and Martha Stewart remain loyal to Parvin Klein, a colorist who perfected an iconic hair color.
content: The Bergdorf blonde is now taking meetings at the Regency Hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meredith Mendelsohn
title: Sea Creatures From the Deep, Captured in Glass, Rise at Mystic Seaport
description: A new show of marine invertebrates, modeled in Germany nearly 150 years ago, helps tell a story about the Connecticut coast today.
content: An enterprising father and son in Dresden, Germany, Leopold and Rudolf Blaschka, found success in the 19th century hand-blowing glass models of marine invertebrates and selling them to universities and natural history museums around the world, from New England to Tokyo. Harvard and Cornell bought around a thousand, in total, by mail order in the 1870s and 1880s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christoph Koettl
title: Satellite imagery shows a water plant in Gaza City burned down amid a dire water shortage.
description: It was not clear what caused the fire, or how recently the plant had been operating.
content: Fire has gutted a water treatment plant on the outskirts of Gaza City, satellite images captured on Thursday and Friday show — the latest evidence of damage to water infrastructure amid an increasingly dire shortage of clean water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Where the 9/11 Dead Are Not Forgotten at Guantánamo Bay
description: Victims’ relatives leave memory stones and messages at a site that is walking distance from the court where the four men accused of conspiring in the plot have yet to be tried.
content: Stones and seashells for people killed in the Sept. 11 attacks began appearing at a signpost at Guantánamo Bay a few years ago, not far from the courtroom for war crimes cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: SpaceX Makes Progress in 2nd Launch of Giant Moon and Mars Rocket
description: The journeys of Starship’s two parts ended in separate explosions. But the engineers at Elon Musk’s spaceflight company overcame problems that marred the rocket’s first flight in April.
content: SpaceX, Elon Musk's spaceflight company, launched its Starship rocket from the coast of South Texas on Saturday, a mammoth vehicle that could alter the future of space transportation and help NASA return astronauts to the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peniel E. Joseph
title: Why We Have to Reckon With the Real Malcolm X
description: Malcolm X still looms over our current moment. But the version of the man that we meet now is much more human, relatable, problematic and inspirational, for all his flaws.
content: When Anthony Davis’s opera “X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X,” which is currently being revived at the Metropolitan Opera in New York, premiered in the mid-1980s, it seemed like a radical act of elevation: The opera lent grand pathos to the story of Malcolm X by giving his life the arc of a tragic hero. And at that moment, Malcolm X was a hero, achieving a grandeur on the world stage in death beyond what he had achieved in life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darby Saxbe
title: This Is Not the Way to Help Depressed Teenagers
description: Large-scale, “light touch” interventions have backfired.
content: Ever since the pandemic, when rates of teenage suicide, anxiety and depression spiked, policymakers around the world have pushed to make mental-health resources more broadly available to young people through programming in schools and on social media platforms.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Postpone Social Security for the Sake of the Young?
description: Readers discuss a guest essay that said older Americans need to rethink their retirement expectations.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Nov. 11-17
description: “Quit” is easy, but being a word scholar is hard.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ameera Harouda, Aaron Boxerman and Karen Zraick
title: Patients and Workers Leave Gaza Hospital Days After Israeli Raid
description: Some said they were ordered to evacuate Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City. The military said it had agreed to a request by the hospital director to help people leave safely.
content: Wounded patients, medical workers and hundreds of displaced Palestinians left the Gaza Strip’s largest hospital complex on Saturday, a witness and a hospital doctor said, days after Israeli troops stormed the complex in search of Hamas command centers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Here is what to know about Saturday’s SpaceX launch.
description: SpaceX’s Starship, the most powerful rocket ever built, lifted off for a second test flight on Saturday and reached an altitude of about 90 miles above Earth before engineers lost contact with it.
content: SpaceX’s Starship, the most powerful rocket ever built, lifted off for a second test flight on Saturday and reached an altitude of about 90 miles above Earth before engineers lost contact with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: ‘It’s Like I Am Blind’: Waiting for Asylum in a British Hotel
description: With the contentious Rwanda plan in disarray, experts say the U.K. government should focus on a huge backlog of asylum cases, including 50,000 people in hotels.
content: Every morning, Mohammed Al Muhandes wakes up in a hotel in Leeds, England, and wonders how to pass the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Startling Evidence on Learning Loss Is In
description: The effects of the pandemic on children are persistent and require urgent attention.
content: In the thick of the Covid-19 pandemic, Congress sent $190 billion in aid to schools, stipulating that 20 percent of the funds had to be used for reversing learning setbacks. At the time, educators knew that the impact on how children learn would be significant, but the extent was not yet known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kozinn
title: David Del Tredici, Who Set ‘Alice’ to Music, Dies at 86
description: A Pulitzer Prize-winning composer, he was an experimentalist who redefined himself, becoming identified with a lush style called the New Romanticism.
content: David Del Tredici, a Pulitzer Prize-winning American composer who began as an experimentalist but became best known for a midcareer shift toward a style that came to be called the New Romanticism, which yielded a series of rich-hued, tuneful pieces based on Lewis Carroll’s “Alice” stories, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Europe Moves to Fill Weapons Gap Amid Doubts About U.S. Commitment to Ukraine
description: Germany, Norway, Britain and others are increasing weapons production to help Kyiv. But the aid may be coming too late as winter looms and Ukraine’s counteroffensive against Russia stalls.
content: Faced with growing American reluctance to send more military aid to Ukraine, European leaders are moving to fill the gap, vowing new support for Kyiv as it battles Russia in a war in Europe’s backyard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Colombia to Sterilize Pablo Escobar’s ‘Cocaine Hippos’
description: The drug kingpin brought four hippos to his estate in the 1980s. Officials estimate that about 170 now roam Colombia, and say the population must be controlled to protect the country’s ecosystem.
content: When the Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar was killed in 1993, most of the animals he had imported as pets — zebras, giraffes, kangaroos and rhinoceroses — died or were transferred to zoos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Why Is the College Board Pushing to Expand Advanced Placement?
description: This year, taxpayers paid the nonprofit at least $90 million for A.P. tests that many students failed.
content: For the past two decades, the College Board has moved aggressively to expand the number of high school students taking Advanced Placement courses and tests — in part by pitching the program to low-income students and the schools that serve them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Marvel
title: I’m a Climate Scientist. I’m Not Screaming Into the Void Anymore.
description: Something has changed in the United States, and not just the climate.
content: Two and a half years ago, when I was asked to help write the most authoritative report on climate change in the United States, I hesitated. Did we really need another warning of the dire consequences of climate change in this country? The answer, legally, was yes: Congress mandates that the National Climate Assessment be updated every four years or so. But after four previous assessments and six United Nations reports since 1990, I was skeptical that what we needed to address climate change was yet another report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: This Chocolate Chess Pie Is a Dessert Checkmate
description: It’s the perfect move for a gathering where some people want pie, some want chocolate and everyone wants something sweet.
content: Butter, chocolate, sugar, eggs, vanilla, cocoa, salt. Those ingredients make up Vaughn Vreeland’s new chocolate chess pie (above), a veritable litany of all the baking stuffs we want when the weather turns cold and the yule log turns warm. Made with a store-bought pie crust (or a half-recipe of this foolproof pie dough), it’s the perfect move for a gathering where some people want pie, some want chocolate and everyone wants something sweet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Federal Prosecutor Asks Judge to Strip New York of Control Over Rikers
description: Manhattan’s top federal prosecutor joined the Legal Aid Society and other lawyers representing people detained in the jail complex in calling for a takeover.
content: The federal government on Friday formally joined an effort to strip Mayor Eric Adams’s administration of control over Rikers Island, asking a judge to hand oversight of the troubled jail complex to an outside authority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall, Amanda Taub, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Saumya Khandelwal
title: Chapter 5: An Unlikely Escape Route
description: Here was the paradox of being a woman in modern India. Sometimes a path from the oppression of patriarchy was marriage to a man willing to help challenge that system.
content: For Nasreen, getting to New Delhi after she ran away from her family and the betrothal they had arranged for her was a daring feat. But surviving there tested her determination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: French Senator Accused of Drugging Fellow Lawmaker
description: Joël Guerriau, a centrist representing a region of western France, is under investigation over suspicion that he spiked a colleague’s drink with the intention of sexually assaulting her.
content: A French senator is under investigation on accusations that he spiked the drink of a fellow lawmaker with drugs this past week with an intent to sexually assault her, the Paris prosecutor’s office said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: The Bloody, 76-Hour Battle on a Tiny Atoll That Helped End World War II
description: The Battle of Tarawa, in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, took a heavy toll on American forces and led to outrage at home.
content: Over three days of intense fighting, thousands of soldiers perished on beaches and in the ocean for a prize — a strategic speck of coral sand and its critical air strip, in the middle of the Pacific — that would help decide the outcome of World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Dying Anticorruption Crusader Considers His Life’s Own Misdeeds
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 18, 2023.
content: “When everybody’s quiet, you just whisper and everybody can hear you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Single-Use Plastics Ban Overturned by Canadian Court
description: Steven Guilbeault, Canada’s environment minister, said the government was “strongly considering” an appeal of the federal court’s ruling.
content: Plastic bags have been disappearing from the checkout lines of Canadian retailers after the federal government banned them last year, along with a handful of other single-use plastic items such as straws and disposable takeout cutlery. But just as businesses and consumers were adapting, a court ruling upended the policy, a key part of Canada’s effort to be among the “world leaders in fighting plastic pollution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Jason Gutierrez
title: Powerful Quake Shakes Southern Philippines, Killing at Least 7
description: The 6.7-magnitude earthquake struck near General Santos City, where hundreds were injured, and schools and shopping malls were closed.
content: A powerful underwater earthquake shook the southern Philippines on Friday, killing several people, damaging a school, shopping malls and dozens of homes, and knocking out power across villages, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: For the Holidays, These May Be the Best Gifts
description: For my annual giving guide, these three nonprofits are the top reader favorites.
content: Wondering what to give friends and relatives this holiday season? Here are ideas for gifts that change lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: F1 in Las Vegas: A Roaring Spectacle for Fans, but a Huge Headache for Locals
description: The flashy adult playground shrouds itself in black tarp to block views of the racing spectacle from prying (unticketed) eyes. Its transformation has become a long-term, costly nuisance for locals.
content: Rajine Jones has a front-row seat to the Las Vegas Grand Prix, one of the most audacious events to roar into a city built on spectacle. Not that she will be able to see it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman
title: ‘Subway Mania’ Brings the Cartoonish World of Pro Wrestling to Commuters
description: The wrestling superfan, Tim Rivera, leads a troupe of performers that cosplay as their childhood heroes in front of unsuspecting subway riders.
content: For many New Yorkers, the city’s subways are the performance spaces they encounter most often. Everyday, dancers and musicians put on a subterranean revue that uses mass transit as a stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Cassie Settles Lawsuit Accusing Sean Combs of Rape and Abuse
description: The R&B singer Casandra Ventura and the music mogul did not disclose terms of the settlement, which came one day after Ms. Ventura filed an explosive complaint.
content: Sean Combs and the singer Cassie have reached a settlement just one day after she filed an explosive lawsuit accusing the hip-hop mogul of rape and numerous instances of physical abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Axe Is Sharp
description: Biden should aim more barbs at Trump, not at fellow Democrats.
content: David Axelrod is not a prick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Corey Schreppel, Dan Powell and Marion Lozano
title: Emergency Pod: Sam Altman is Out at Open AI
description: “Probably the most shocking tech story of the year.”
content: Sam Altman, the chief executive of Open AI, was pushed out of the company by its board of directors on Friday. The news was a complete shock to much of the company’s employee base and to its largest corporate partner, Microsoft. Silicon Valley insiders are scrambling to get answers on exactly what happened and why the board’s decision seemed so abrupt. We rundown what we know and the many things we still don’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: The Fear and Tension That Led to Sam Altman’s Ouster at OpenAI
description: The departure of the high-profile boss of the San Francisco company drew attention to a philosophical rift among the people building new A.I. systems.
content: Over the last year, Sam Altman led OpenAI to the adult table of the technology industry. Thanks to its hugely popular ChatGPT chatbot, the San Francisco start-up was at the center of an artificial intelligence boom, and Mr. Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, had become one of the most recognizable people in tech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian Kimble
title: Black Thought Is Here for ‘The Gilded Age’ and ‘1883’
description: Tariq Trotter, the Roots frontman and author of the new book “The Upcycled Self,” loves a period drama when it’s done right.
content: Despite earning worldwide acclaim as the frontman of the Roots and achieving a degree of ubiquity when they became the house band for “The Tonight Show,” Tariq Trotter, also known as Black Thought, is an introvert and a bit of an enigma. There’s a good chance that fans who know every Roots verse still know little about the man behind them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
title: Is Israel’s Military Strategy to Eradicate Hamas Working?
description: Israel is making progress in ground control of Gaza, but it has not vanquished Hamas or freed most of the hostages. And international condemnation of civilian casualties is growing.
content: The Israeli military’s seizure of Al-Shifa Hospital, Gaza’s largest medical complex, is central to the military strategy at the heart of the ground invasion: Eradicate Hamas and free roughly 240 hostages taken during the Oct. 7 surprise attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clair MacDougall and Monika Pronczuk
title: Liberia’s President Concedes Election Defeat in a Knife-Edge Vote
description: President George Weah, a former soccer star whose administration had weathered accusations of corruption, announced that he had lost his bid for re-election to Joseph Boakai, a 78-year-old former vice president.
content: Liberia’s president, George Weah, conceded defeat on Friday night in his bid for a second term, after a tight runoff against Joseph Boakai, a 78-year-old political veteran, in an election that was considered a test of democracy in the West African nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Colorado Judge Keeps Trump on Ballot but Finds He ‘Engaged in Insurrection’
description: A district court judge ruled that former President Donald J. Trump “engaged in insurrection” but said the disqualification clause of the 14th Amendment did not apply to him.
content: A Colorado judge ruled on Friday that former President Donald J. Trump could remain on the primary ballot in the state, rejecting the argument that the 14th Amendment prevents him from holding office again — but doing so on relatively narrow grounds that lawyers for the voters seeking to disqualify him said they would appeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy, Erin Nolan and Olivia Bensimon
title: Thousands Gather in Pro-Palestinian Protests Across New York City
description: In Brooklyn and in Manhattan, multiple rallies drew large crowds calling for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.
content: Thousands of people took to the streets on Friday evening in the latest instance of what has become near daily protests in New York City over the Israel-Hamas war. This time, pro-Palestinian demonstrators held banners and signs demanding a cease-fire in the bombardment of Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas, Leonardo Coelho and Flávia Milhorance
title: Fan Dies at Taylor Swift Concert in Rio’s Extreme Heat
description: Many fans fell sick at the show, where temperatures broke records and concertgoers complained of a lack of water. The pop star postponed Saturday’s show.
content: One fan died and many others fainted at Taylor Swift’s concert on Friday in Rio de Janeiro, where temperatures felt like nearly 140 degrees Fahrenheit, a record for the city, and fans said they struggled to get water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Rumbles in the Senate and the Supreme Court — and the Movie You’ll Never See
description: Here’s what caught my eye this week.
content: There was a lot of news this week, and I could not write a column about every event. Instead, here are some quick thoughts on a few events that caught my eye. You can think of this as something like a lightning round.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: How Do I Make My Building Turn on the Heat (or Turn It Up)?
description: New York City requires building owners to provide heat between Oct. 1 and May 31.
content: Q: Our co-op building near Gramercy Park is not following New York City heating laws. There’s been no heat after 10 p.m. so far this year, and there was rarely heat at night last year. There is no heat at 6 a.m. — it comes on at 7 a.m. The windows are drafty and need to be replaced, which makes the problem worse. A vote by co-op shareholders on replacing the windows did not pass. Several of us have offered to pay to replace the windows ourselves, but we were told we cannot do this. What can we do to make sure the building is properly heated?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: How I Learned to Shave
description: Things our dads taught us, whether they intended to or not.
content: Things our dads taught us, whether they intended to or not.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Two Books for a Happier Thanksgiving
description: A glamorous family memoir; a fictional dinner party.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Ohio Priest Who Sexually Abused Boys Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
description: The priest, Michael Zacharias, had enabled the victims’ drug addictions by paying them money in exchange for sexual acts, prosecutors said.
content: An Ohio priest who coerced three boys into engaging in sexual acts as children and abused their addiction to opioids as teenagers and adults, paying them money that funded their drug habits in exchange for sex, was sentenced to life in prison on Friday, the Justice Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: Why Revel Shut Down Its Moped Service in New York
description: Revel’s ridership has declined steeply amid safety concerns and growing competition from Citi Bike and personal e-bikes and mopeds.
content: When Revel brought 68 electric mopeds to a Brooklyn storefront in 2018, it set out to show New Yorkers that getting around the city could be fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: Don Walsh, Record-Breaking Deep Sea Explorer, Dies at 92
description: In 1960, aboard the submersible Trieste, he and a scientist made a historic dive of nearly seven miles into the ocean’s deepest spot.
content: Don Walsh, a pioneering U.S. Navy explorer who, along with the scientist Jacques Piccard, broke the record for human deep submergence by descending nearly seven miles to the ocean’s deepest spot, died on Nov. 12 at his home in Myrtle Point, Ore. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 18, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 18, 2023.
content: An article on Page 6 this weekend about a new biopic on the civil rights leader Bayard Rustin misstates the middle initial of an author. He is Michael G. Long, not Michael C. Long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Congress Isn’t a Schoolyard. Time to Deal With Toxic Immaturity.
description: Young men need to look for role models outside the attention economy.
content: On Tuesday, Republican Senator Markwayne Mullin of Oklahoma decided to settle a social media beef in the middle of a Senate hearing titled “Standing Up Against Corporate Greed.” Mullin read from a months-old post by Sean O’Brien, the president of the Teamsters, in which O’Brien called Mullin “a clown & fraud,” mocked the senator with an unflattering photo and the hashtag #LittleManSyndrome, and challenged the senator to a fight: “Anyplace, Anytime cowboy,” O’Brien boasted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jackie Cooperman
title: How a Political Insider Spends Her Sundays
description: Tricia Shimamura keeps busy by welcoming immigrants, helping women get into politics and chasing around her two young children on the Upper East Side.
content: Tricia Shimamura spends her days crisscrossing the city as the director of community affairs for Mark Levine, the Manhattan borough president. She helps with everything from street fairs to welcoming new immigrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: How to Keep Your Bank From Closing All Your Accounts
description: Banks have suddenly shut down the accounts of scores of customers. Here’s how you can avoid becoming one of them.
content: Having a checking account is a privilege, not a right, but most people forget this until they lose access to their accounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: In Hurricane’s Sudden Fury, Acapulco’s Yacht Crews Went Down With Their Ships
description: Hurricane Otis left a trail of destruction and death but inflicted its worst blow on the yacht crews and other boat workers who are a pillar of the tourism industry.
content: On the night Hurricane Otis barreled into Acapulco, Mexico, Saúl Parra Morales received a video that only hours before would have seemed unbelievable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Chiusano
title: George Santos Is More Dangerous Than You Know
description: Mr. Santos has exposed just how much craziness the Republican Party is willing to tolerate in pursuit of narrow partisan gains.
content: By now, you probably know a lot about George Santos, the congressman who scammed with abandon and made up almost everything. His college diploma. His grandparents who “survived” the Holocaust. Many of his most egregious untruths were unveiled by The New York Times last December. This week, the House Ethics Committee went even further, reporting that he had used campaign money for Atlantic City trips and things marked “Botox.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Amy Chang Chien
title: Bedbug Anxiety Has Come for Asia, and the Pest Killers Are Here for It
description: Outbreaks in France and South Korea have people across Asia on high alert for bedbugs. Exterminators in the region say business is booming.
content: It’s a good time to be a professional bug killer in Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The War Turns Gaza Into a ‘Graveyard’ for Children
description: Thousands of children have been killed in the enclave since the Israeli assault began, officials in Gaza say. The Israeli military says it takes “all feasible precautions” to avoid civilian deaths.
content: Barefoot and weeping, Khaled Joudeh, 9, hurried toward the dozens of bodies wrapped in white burial shrouds, blankets and rugs outside the overcrowded morgue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Viktor Belenko, Who Defected to the West in a Jet Fighter, Dies at 76
description: Among the highest-profile figures to flee the Soviet Union, he brought with him a secret weapon and firsthand experience behind the Iron Curtain.
content: On a clear late summer day in 1976, a plane popped up on the radar just off the coast of the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. It had been flying a mere 100 feet off the water, low enough to avoid detection. Now, suddenly, it climbed up to 20,000 feet. Clearly, the pilot wanted to be seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Havrilesky
title: Crushing It
description: The minivan life takes a turn when the kids are old enough to drive.
content: My life is pretty relaxing right now, but there’s a chilling period each day that derails all of my sleekest and sturdiest emotional trains, and that’s the dark corridor between 8:30 and 8:42 a.m., when my two daughters leave for high school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Apple Says It Will Improve the Green vs. Blue Texting Experience
description: Longstanding texting problems between Android and Apple owners will ease next year. Among other changes, users will be able to send better-quality videos and photos.
content: Starting next year, it should be less frustrating for iPhone and Android users to text one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: The Critics Scoffed. Nora Roberts Just Kept Writing.
description: At 73, a titan of the romance world talks about how she redefined a genre that was all too easy to dismiss.
content: It’s no exaggeration to say that the writer Nora Roberts has shaped how generations of people, especially women, think about relationships and sex — not to mention, what makes a great story. Before Roberts, the romance genre was dominated by tepid and virginal women who were overpowered by brooding men. Roberts changed all that by thrusting romance into the modern era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Pardon Recipients Seek to Sell Trump on His Own Sentencing Law
description: The Republican front-runner has a history of making racist statements, but some advisers think highlighting his signature law could help increase support among Black voters and potentially swing the election.
content: In early July, former President Donald J. Trump received a somewhat unlikely visitor at his golf club and estate in Bedminster, N.J.: Michael Harris, the founder of Death Row Records, who had been imprisoned for drug trafficking and attempted murder, came to meet privately with the man who had pardoned him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Thanksgiving Meal Prep
description: Rebecca Goldstein and Rachel Fabi’s puzzle brings everything you could possibly need to the table.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arielle Paul
title: Dubai’s Costly Water World
description: The city has spent billions of dollars to provide fresh water to its residents and tourist attractions, but experts say the efforts are straining the Persian Gulf’s natural resources.
content: For a desert city, Dubai appears like a water wonderland. Visitors can scuba dive in the world’s deepest pool or ski inside a mega mall where penguins play in freshly made snow. A fountain — billed as the world’s largest — sprays more than 22,000 gallons of water into the air, synchronized to music from surrounding speakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Cybersecurity Lawsuit That Boards Are Talking About
description: An S.E.C. lawsuit against a software company hacked by Russian state actors in 2020 could affect how companies handle cybersecurity risks.
content: For the last month, an under-the-radar lawsuit has privately been a hot topic of conversation in Fortune 500 boardrooms and corporate security departments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, November 19, 2023
description: Can you sort 8 historical events? The Silk Road, “The Hesitant Fiancée”, and the Clean Air Act.
content: Can you sort 8 historical events? The Silk Road, “The Hesitant Fiancée”, and the Clean Air Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather, James Surdam, Rebecca Suner and Jake Grovum
title: How to Become a Cricket Expert for the Cricket World Cup Final
description: The world’s top cricket teams have spent the past weeks battling to determine which is the best at the Cricket World Cup, one of the most popular sporting events in the world. But in some countries, including the U.S., cricket barely hits sports fans’ radars — which is a shame! With the World Cup final set for Sunday, here’s what you need to know to understand a game that has captivated fans for centuries.
content: The world’s top cricket teams have spent the past weeks battling to determine which is the best at the Cricket World Cup, one of the most popular sporting events in the world. But in some countries, including the U.S., cricket barely hits sports fans’ radars — which is a shame! With the World Cup final set for Sunday, here’s what you need to know to understand a game that has captivated fans for centuries.
source.name: The New York Times
